claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.

rejected_evidence.quote: Estimates of overall inactivated vaccine protective efficacy are clearly impacted by antigenic differences between vaccine and circulating viruses, with highest levels of effectiveness reported for H1 viruses [25] and lowest levels for influenza B.
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This quote supports the claim by explicitly stating that antigenic differences (which can arise from mutations during production) between the vaccine and circulating viruses impact the effectiveness of inactivated (egg- or cell-based) influenza vaccines.

rejected_evidence.quote: Effectiveness of inactivated influenza vaccines varied substantially with antigenic match from the 2004-2005 season to the 2006-2007 season. J Infect Dis 2009 199.
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This quote provides evidence that the effectiveness of inactivated (egg- or cell-based) influenza vaccines is affected by how well the vaccine antigens match circulating strains, which can be reduced by mutations acquired during production.

rejected_evidence.quote: Clinical efficacy of cell culture derived and egg derived inactivated subunit influenza vaccines in healthy adults. Clin Infect Dis 2010 51 997 1004.
rejected_evidence.original_explanation: This reference to a study comparing cell culture and egg-derived vaccines is relevant because such studies often discuss the impact of production-related mutations on vaccine efficacy, supporting the claim that these vaccines can develop mutations that reduce effectiveness.
